title: Ticket #7668: Make Python bindings Schedd constructor location_ad argument optional
description:
The Schedd constructor is an overloaded function with two signatures, 
    __init__(_object* self)
    __init__(_object* self, ClassAdWrapper location_ad)
The intent is that in the first form, it finds the local schedd, and in the other form, it contacts a remote schedd. This works, but because the location ad is required, if you're writing a wrapper function where someone may or may not pass in a location ad, you have to do something like this: 
def get_schedd(location_ad = None):
    if location_ad is None:
        return Schedd()
    else:
        return Schedd(location_ad)
instead of the more convenient 
def get_schedd(location_ad = None):
    return Schedd(location_ad)
which right now emits an error like 
Boost.Python.ArgumentError: Python argument types in
    Schedd.__init__(Schedd, NoneType)
did not match C++ signature:
    __init__(_object* self)
    __init__(_object* self, ClassAdWrapper location_ad)

I checked another constructor for consistency, Startd, and found a similar problem: 

$ python -c "import htcondor; htcondor.Startd(None)"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/jkarpel/.python/lib/python3.7/site-packages/htcondor/_lock.py", line 77, in wrapper
    rv = func(*args, **kwargs)
TypeError: No registered converter was able to produce a C++ rvalue of type ClassAdWrapper from this Python object of type NoneType
which is confusing because the C++ declaration implies that it can take a None as its argument. It must be failing internally, once the None has already been passed through Boost into our code.

In all these cases, passing the location ad as None should work identically to not passing it at all (and it should always be called either ad or location_ad; they are mixed right now (maybe we save that for a later date...)).
remarks: fixed as a side effect of #7670
